Several of the voices heard on World Tour were imported to provide
SPECIFIC MATERIAL FOR THE SERIES, Dr.,Om CHOPRA, PRINCIPAL OF A
HIGH SCHOOL IN AmBALA, INDIA, AND THREE GRADUATE STUDENTS FROM INDIA
WHO ARE STUDYING AT St. LOUIS UNIVERSITIES, CAME TO THE STUD.IO TO
RECOUNT STORIES OF THE SCHOOL LIFE OF BOYS AND GIRLS IN THEIR COUN¬
TRY AND DESCRIBE THE CLIMATE, MODES OF TRANSPORTATION, TYPES OF
HOUSES, AND WILD LIFE WHICH CHARACTERIZE VARIOUS SECTIONS OF INDIA.
Let me cite an example of how portions of three recordings were in¬
corporated INTO THE INITIAL PROGRAM OF WORLD TOUR. THE OPENING SEC¬
TION IS AN ON-THE-SPOT DESCRIPTION OF NORTH AFRICA MADE BY MrS. COREY
AS HER PLANE LANDED IN LIBYA. A SECOND REPORT PRESENTS MRS. WANCY
COLLINGS, WIFE OF A RETIRED BRITISH ARMY GENERAL, WHO LIVED FOR MANY
years in Africa and the Near East. Interviewed in New York by KSLH
STAFF MEMBERS WHO MET HER WHILE ATTENDING A CONVENTION, SHE GIVES
A FIRST-HAND ACCOUNT OF A VISIT TO THE DESERT TENT HOMES OF THE
Beduoin Arabs. In the third part of the broadcast, Wassef Youssef
Wassef, student of clinical psychology at Washington University and
native of Cairo, describes a trip to the oasis of Siwa, "Egypt. Be¬
tween EACH REPORT COMMENTS BY A NARRATOR POINT UP THE SIGNIFICANCE
OF THE MATERIAL, SET THE SCENE FOR THE NEXT REPORTER, OR ADD PER¬
TINENT INFORMATION.
Reactions to the first series of seven programs indicate that they
ARE FILLING A REAL NEED FOR TEACHERS BY STIMULATING BOYS AND GIRLS
TO WANT TO KNOW THEIR WORLD NEIGHBORS.
--Ken Wright, WUOT
